subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... Well, no.  Orthodox spelling worked well for Southern English around 1500. And how good the writing system is in no way influences what s going to happen
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> I know the goal might be to produce something like Spanish with it's
> universal spelling, phonemic letters and huge variety of accents. But
> this can not be done with English in its current state. The various
> accents have evolved in an incompatible manner over the centuries
> because the language was insufficiently phonetic to begin with.

Well, no. Orthodox spelling worked well for Southern English around 1500.
And how good the writing system is in no way influences what's going to
happen to the language: Latin broke up into a whole bunch of mutually
unintelligible languages, anything up to 45 of them depending on how
you count -- yet its orthography was excellent for the time it was
written down.

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
I am he that buries his friends alive and drowns them and draws them
alive again from the water. I came from the end of a bag, but no bag
went over me. I am the friend of bears and the guest of eagles. I am
Ringwinner and Luckwearer; and I am Barrel-rider. --Bilbo to Smaug

> I know the goal might be to produce something like Spanish with it's
> universal spelling, phonemic letters and huge variety of accents. But
> this can not be done with English in its current state. The various
> accents have evolved in an incompatible manner over the centuries
> because the language was insufficiently phonetic to begin with.

Well, no.  Orthodox spelling worked well for Southern English around 1500.
And how good the writing system is in no way influences what's going to
happen to the language:  Latin broke up into a whole bunch of mutually
unintelligible languages, anything up to 45 of them depending on how
you count -- yet its orthography was excellent for the time it was
written down.
